<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.

- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.

DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_shmem_open:
```c
int metal_shmem_open(const char *name, size_t size,
		     struct metal_io_region **result)
{
	struct metal_page_size *ps;
	int fd, error;

	error = metal_shmem_open_generic(name, size, result);
	if (!error)
		return error;

	error = metal_open(name, 1);
	if (error < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "Failed to open shmem file :%s\n", name);
		return error;
	}
	fd = error;

	/* Iterate through page sizes in decreasing order. */
	metal_for_each_page_size_down(ps) {
		if (ps->page_size > 2 * size)
			continue;
		error = metal_shmem_try_map(ps, fd, size, result);
		if (!error)
			break;
	}

	close(fd);
	return error;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
Other controlling expressions in the function do not need further investigation for Rule 14.3 because they are not invariant: 
- "error = metal_shmem_open_generic(name, size, result); if (!error) return error;" — the condition uses 'error' assigned by a function call, so it is not a compile-time invariant.
- "error = metal_open(name, 1); if (error < 0) { ... return error; }" — 'error' is set by a runtime call, so the condition is not invariant.
- The inner tests (ps->page_size > 2 * size) and (if (!error) break) depend on 'ps', 'size', and 'error' which are runtime values (ps is the loop variable and error is set each iteration), so they are not invariant unless the loop construct itself causes invariance. 
The only fragment that requires investigation against MISRA C:2023 Rule 14.3 is the loop macro 'metal_for_each_page_size_down(ps)' because its expansion may produce an invariant controlling expression (or an intentional infinite loop). The macro expansion must be inspected to determine whether the controlling expression is invariant or otherwise conforms to the rule (including allowed exceptions for deliberate infinite loops or the specific do-while exception).
